data.text: Contents
Introduction

One of the core roles of the MSE NHS Foundation Trust is to provide end of life care. In recent years it has been identified that patients dying in acute hospitals can experience very poor care (National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death 2009, Neuberger 2013, Dying without Dignity 2015), including poor symptom control and communication. Often involvement with the patient and family in end of life decision making is deficient. Supporting people to die in comfort and with dignity for themselves, their family and carers is a priority function of the NHS (NEoLCP, 2011).

How people die remains a lasting memory of relatives, carers', health and social care staff and there is evidence that the final elements of care have an impact on the bereavement process (Department of Health 2008). These guidelines aim to support staff to meet their responsibility to provide the best possible care at the end of life.

The guidelines incorporate up to date national best practice recommendations for end of life care in acute hospitals (Leadership Alliance for Care of the Dying Alliance 2014, Actions for End of Life Care 2014, and NICE 2015) and link directly to the End of Life Care Strategy. Nationally, acute trusts have been required to implement and embed services that are aligned to deliver the ‘Ambitions for Palliative and End of Life Care, 2015-2020' and updated Ambitions Framework for 2021-2026. The National Palliative and End of Life Care Partnership (2015) developed the framework for action to support palliative and end of life care becoming a priority at local level.
Scope

The purpose of these multidisciplinary guidelines is to provide guidance and a framework for the multidisciplinary teams caring for patients and their families to ensure high quality compassionate care is provided at the end of life to the level of best practice:
To provide clear instructions and guidance for care planning and care in the last year of life.
To provide clear instructions for care of the deceased person.
To provide clear instructions for after death care and support for the bereaved.
This policy excludes procedures following a neonatal or child death.

These guidelines are inclusive of all clinical personnel involved with patient's care in all settings – including wards, emergency departments, day units, theatres, and outpatient and imaging departments. The guidelines also provide instruction to ancillary and support services, including managers and housekeeping / domestic personnel who provide refreshments, mortuary staff, porters, bereavement personnel and faith leaders.
Definitions

table_items.text: People who are approaching the end of life when they are likely to die in the next 12 months. This includes people whose death is imminent (expected within a few hours or days) and those with: Advanced, progressive, incurable conditions General frailty and co-existing conditions that mean they are expected to die in 12 months Existing conditions if they are at risk of dying from a sudden acute crisis Life threatening acute conditions caused by sudden catastrophic events
The period of time covering the last year of person's life
The period of time covering the last days and hours of person's life
Clinically assisted hydration includes intravenous and subcutaneous fluid therapy – ‘drip'
Clinically assisted nutrition includes intravenous feeding, feeding by percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG), naso-gastric (NG) and radiologically inserted gastrostomy (RIG)
Used in these guidelines to refer to those people important to the patient, including carers, relatives, and the patients identified next of kin for the dying patient

Next of kin is the person who is identified by the patient as who they wish to be notified in the event of death. This can also be the person with whom the health and social care team consult with. It is important to note that the next of kin, term doesn't mean anything in law or come with any automatic legal powers and should not be confused with Legal Power of Attorney.

Advance care planning is a voluntary process of discussion about future care between an individual and their care providers, irrespective of discipline, whereby an individual who has capacity reviews their understanding of their illness and prognosis and how this may affect them. This may include decisions and recording of choices (advance statement) regarding their care and treatment or an advance decision to refuse specified treatment, so that their decisions can be referred to by those responsible for their care in the event of them losing capacity.
Best interests (in the context of patients lacking capacity to make a particular decision)

Any decision made, or anything done for a person who lacks capacity to make specific decisions, must be in the person's best interest. The Mental Capacity Act 2005 (England and Wales) sets out how a best interest decision should be made. Any staff involved in the care of a person who lacks capacity should make sure a record is kept of the process of working out the best interest of that person for each relevant decision, setting out: How the decision about the person's best interest was reached What the reasons for reaching the decision were Who was consulted to help work out the best interest What particular factors were taken into account
Abbreviation meaning "when necessary" (from the Latin "pro re nata", for an occasion that has arisen, as circumstances require, as needed).
Electronic prescribing and medicines administration system used by the Trust

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities Oncology Governance Committee
Responsible for:
Leading on the development or major review of this policy.
Is responsible for ensuring the procedural guidelines are developed taking into account relevant best practice and legislative requirements.
All Clinical Divisional Governance Groups Responsible for:
Reviewing and undertaking actions in regards of the implementation of end of life care within their Division, including on-going review of processes detailed in this policy.
Ensuring training and competencies for relevant staff is up to date.
Reviewing and undertaking actions related to any incident within the division in relation to this policy.
Ensuring that safe systems, practices and training programmes are implemented within divisional patient areas where the dying patient is cared for.
Ensuring all procedural documents under their remit is appropriate, up to date and available at the point of need.
End of Life Working Party
Responsible for:
Leading on the development or major review of this policy.
Is responsible for ensuring these procedural guidelines are developed taking into account relevant best practice and legislative requirements.
Individual responsibilities
4.2.1 Managing Director

As the Trust's accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring the MSE NHS Foundation Trust has robust and up to date procedural documents in place to govern and guide activities. The implementation of this duty is delegated to the Information Asset Owners (IAOs).
4.2.2 Sponsor – Medical Director (Information Asset Owner)
Is responsible for ensuring the policies are reviewed in a timely manner and for overseeing the development and implementation.
As an organisation wide procedural document, the Asset Owner is the Medical Director. The implementation of this responsibility may be delegated to a procedural document author.
4.2.3 Senior Medical Staff Responsible for:
Supporting the dissemination and implementation of this policy and procedural documents within the areas of their responsibility.
Ensuring that this policy and procedures are followed at all times within their area of responsibility.
Leading clinical decision making and communicating with the multi-disciplinary team in end of life care.
4.2.4 Medical Staff Responsible for:
Familiarising themselves with this policy and implementation of all procedural documents as part of their normal duties and responsibilities.
Attending training and updates as required and maintaining their professional documentation record.
Delivering clinical care as outlined in this policy and associated clinical guidelines.
4.2.5 Pharmacist Responsible for:
Assessment of clinical appropriateness of prescriptions as part of routine clinical pharmacy service.
Supporting the implementation of the Essex Palliative and Supportive Care formulary.
Liaising and working collaboratively with the Palliative Care Team in relation to medications management involved in end of life care provision.
4.2.6 Pharmacy Staff Responsible for:
Dispensing and supporting the timely supply of medicines available for symptom control.
Dispensing and supporting the timely supply of anticipatory medication in rapid discharge of end of life patients.
4.2.7 Palliative Care Team Responsible for:
Supporting the dissemination and implementation of this policy and revised procedural documents.
Supporting education programmes and learning needs of staff involved in symptom control, prescribing and management of patients who have end of life care needs.
Attending training and development needs and maintaining their own competency.
Liaising and working collaboratively to supporting the pharmacy team in relation to medications management involved in end of life care provision.
Assessing, planning and delivering clinical care for patients who have complex end of life care needs in line with this and associated clinical guidelines.
4.2.8 Matrons Responsible for:
Supporting the dissemination and implementation of this policy and procedural documents within areas of their responsibility.
Ensuring that guidelines and procedures are followed at all times within their area of responsibility.
Supporting audit, governance and a monitoring programmes and ensure any follow up and action plans are developed and actioned in an appropriate and timely manner.
4.2.9 Ward/Department Managers
Responsible for:
All duties listed under Registered Nurses.
Supporting the dissemination and implementation of this policy and procedural documents. This includes ensuring that staff are able to attend any training required.
Ensuring that this policy and procedures are followed at all times.
Ensuring all staff working within the clinical area has the appropriate and up-to- date training and competencies required and maintain their personal records to this effect.
Ensuring the reporting of any risks or incidents in relation to end of life care and care of the dying patient.
4.2.10 Registered Nurse Responsible for:
Familiarising themselves with this policy and implementation of all procedural documents as part of their normal duties and responsibilities.
Attending training and updates as required, maintaining their professional documentation record.
Delivering clinical care as outlined in this policy and associated clinical guidelines.
Ordering supplies of required medications and maintaining stock control to ensure access to medicines and equipment when caring for the dying.
Providing supervision of nursing students and health care assistants undertaking care of the dying.
Being aware of, and monitoring the patient for side effects and acting accordingly.

Appropriately documenting care, in particular communication and medications on the appropriate tool and inpatient drug chart, in accordance with the Administration of Medicines Policy and Procedures (MSEPO-21128).
4.2.11 Health Care Assistants Responsible for:
Familiarising themselves with this policy and implementation of all procedural documents as part of their normal duties and responsibilities.
Attending training and update as required, maintaining their professional documentation record.
Providing care as outlined in these and associated guidelines under supervision of a Registered Nurse.
4.2.12 All Staff Responsible for:
Familiarising themselves with these procedural documents and co-operating with the development and implementation of all procedural documents as part of their normal duties and responsibilities.
Best practice

Best practice and care at the end of life is in line with the ‘Ambitions for Palliative and End of Life Care 2021-2026', National Palliative and End of Life Care Partnership, 2015 (Table.1) .Services are designed to include strong leadership in End of Life Care, including clear communication pathways with the site management team, senior managers and clinicians in a robust governance framework. All staff caring for patients and their families will have access to the necessary training to develop and maintain appropriate attitude, skills and knowledge to provide high quality end of life care delivered with compassion and competence.

table_items.text: Vision “I can make the last stage of my life as good as possible because everyone works together confidently, honestly and consistently to help me and the people who are important to me, including my carer(s).”
Ambitions for Palliative and End of Life Care
01 Each person is seen as an individual

I, and the people important to me, have opportunities to have honest, informed and timely conversations and to know that I might die soon. I am asked what matters most to me. Those that care for me know that and work with me to do what's possible.
02 Each person gets fair access to care
I live in a society where I get good end of life care regardless of who I am, where I live or the circumstances of my life.
My care is regularly reviewed and every effort is made for me to have the support, care and treatment that might be needed to help me to be as comfortable and as free from distress as possible.

I get the right help at the right time from the right people. I have a team around me who knows my needs and my plans and work together to help me achieve them. I can always reach someone who will listen and respond at any time of the day or night.
05 All staff are prepared to care
Wherever I am, health and care staff bring empathy, skills and expertise and give me competent, confident and compassionate care.
06 Each community is prepared to help

I live in a community where everybody recognises that we all have a role to play in supporting each other in times of crisis and loss. People are ready, willing and confident to have conversations about living and dying well and to support each other in emotional and practical ways.

data.text: Care in the last year of life
Care in the last year of life must ensure the following principles are met:
Recognition and identification of patients who are in their last year of life.
Enable and support the patient in decision making and a coordinate a care plan across all care settings.
On-going holistic assessments of patient's physical, psychosocial, information and spiritual needs to support care plan.
Timely and proactive clinical decision making led by a senior doctor in conjunction with the patient and where appropriate, family, intervening early and managing an uncertain prognosis.
Provide high quality care for all patients in the last year of life receiving hospital care.
Advance Care Planning for all patients who have life limiting conditions. Specific focus on those patients with conditions that may lead to loss of mental capacity.
To reduce hospitalisation by reducing length of stay, rapid discharge management supporting PPC/D and admission avoidance.
Provide care by a competent and confident workforce through training and education.
Advance care planning

Advance Care Planning (ACP) supports a patient to document their choices and thoughts about their care, in particular what matters to them, including where they would want the majority of their care to be provided and where they would prefer to die. Importantly it allows them to document what they would not want to happen. ACP includes consideration of Preferred Priorities of Care/Death (PPC/D).

To record any choices and wishes there is a process which informs various care settings in order to aid communication to ensuring the patient's wishes are known (whether the choices are verbal or documented on the Essex wide ACP tool – ‘IAM' document) care can be planned and coordinated accordingly. If any choices alter, this can be updated. With the patients consent, these wishes are held on the locality Electronic Palliative Care Coordination System (EPaCCS), which can offer valuable support to all clinical teams in decision making and coordinating the correct plan, in particular ensuring all services have access to up to date information in particular in a crisis and for Out of Hours team.

Advance Care Planning (ACP) is a process of discussion between a patient and their care providers. The intention being to make clear a patient's wishes in the context of the future anticipated deterioration of the patient and also the potential loss of capacity to make decisions and/or ability to communicate wishes to others. This often leads to the making of an advance statement such as: an Advance Decision to refuse treatment, a ‘Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation' decision or other types of decision such as putting in place a Lasting Power of Attorney.

When a patient, who is in the last year of life, is receiving care in any setting it is best practice for the clinician/ team to proactively identify what the patient's ACP (esp. PPC/D) wishes are. If they have an advance statement/ACP in place such as the ‘IAM' document, the team must consider these with the patient when making clinical decisions.
Advance decision to refuse treatment (ADRT)

This is a documented decision by a person to refuse a particular treatment in specified circumstances, such as antibiotics, even if their life is at risk. This decision would only come into effect when the person loses capacity at a time that a decision needs to be made. A valid ADRT is legally binding.

Clinicians can also refer to: ‘Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment, A guide for health and social care professionals', NHS Improving Quality 2014. This guide is designed to help health and social care professionals understand and implement the law relating to advance decisions to refuse treatment (ADRT) contained in the Mental Capacity Act (2005).
Mental Capacity
See section  in relation the last days of life care and refer to MSEPO-21103 Mental capacity act policy.

When supporting patients to plan ahead it is important to discuss their wishes in view of their future anticipated deterioration, and in view of their possible accompanied risk of loss of capacity to make decisions and/or ability to communicate wishes to others when they become more unwell. They may wish to consider appointing a Lasting Power of Attorney for health. They can seek legal advice or see the following website for more information:
https://www.gov.uk/power-of-attorney
Decisions regarding Treatment Escalation Planning and Attempting Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) for Patients
It may then be appropriate to consider making a Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary

Resuscitation (DNACPR) decision for patients for whom cardiopulmonary arrest is the end result of a disease process in which appropriate treatment options have been exhausted. Also for those patients for whom successful restoration of the circulation is likely to be followed by duration or quality of life that would be unacceptable to them. It is also essential to identify those patients who would not want CPR to be attempted in the event of a cardio-respiratory arrest and who have capacity to refuse this treatment option.

It is important that the clinical team consider whether both attempting cardiopulmonary resuscitation is appropriate and whether ceilings of treatment are required (TEP). Such considerations should be discussed with the patient and family as appropriate. Please refer to Policy for Decisions Regarding Attempting Cardio-Pulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) for Patients.
Tissue and Organ Donation

Some patients may wish to donate tissue or organs after death. Refer to policy No: MSEPO-21081 Organ and Tissue Donation Policy. Patients dying from cancer will generally be able to donate tissue (usually corneas) rather than organs.

Staff should routinely consider this in end of life care and be proactive in asking and recording the patient wishes. Where a person's wishes regarding organ and tissue donation were not formally recorded (i.e. advance care plan, registered donor) consent can be sought by an appropriately training healthcare professional with person who has a ‘qualifying relationship' (see hierarchy of qualified relatives in the Human Tissue Act). Further advice can be sought from the Tissue coordinator and NHS Blood and Transplant team, who will advise on the next steps, contact via switchboard.
Body donation for anatomical examination

Some patients may have made arrangements for their body to be used for medical teaching purposes by one of the anatomy organisations or express an interest in doing so. Staff should consider this in end of life care and be proactive in asking the patient and their family their wishes. Where the patient is in the last year of life, discussion and support regarding whole body donation can be planned; however as whole body donation can only be consented by the person themselves in life and not on their behalf at death, where this has not been planned it is unlikely to be possible in the last days of life (due to likely capacity and time barriers).

When the patient dies, the executor or next of kin is required to telephone the Anatomy Office as soon as possible after the death occurs, it may be necessary for the nurse caring for the bereaved to support them to notify the Anatomy Office. Where the death occurs in a hospital the body should be transferred to and held in the hospital mortuary pending a decision on acceptance for anatomical examination. The Anatomy Donations Co-ordinator will speak to the doctor issuing the death certificate to ascertain suitability of the body for anatomical examination and subsequently liaise with mortuary team to affect transfer if accepted.
Discharge process in the last year of life

Multi-disciplinary Teams, led by a senior clinician, need to identify patients who are in their last year of life. Regular review should take place in all care settings that the patient attends, including outpatient attendance and during inpatient episodes. All patients who are identified as having end of life care needs should have their discharge planned starting on admission, all planning in line with Discharge Policy. Proactive working across the Multi-Disciplinary Teams is crucial in order to facilitate discharge.

Patients that are identified as being in their last year of life should be considered for referral to services listed below. It is necessary to discuss referral, obtain patient consent for referral and supply with written information.
GP.
District Nursing.
Community Palliative Care Team (where there are complex symptoms and needs only).
Hospice services (inc Day care, Hospice at Home).
Long Term Conditions team.
Basildon only - ‘One Response' (covers all services listed above).
Rapid discharge to home/care home / hospice for end of life care

Where the patient has identified their PPD is their home, Care Home or Hospice, staff should coordinate rapid discharge for end of life care to the place of their choice. All discharge planning is in keeping with discharge policy and informed by an individual assessment of the patients and family's needs. Staff must always use the Rapid Discharge Care Bundle for EOLC.
The rapid discharge for end of life care process and plan must include consideration of:
Care package (Continuing Health Care Fast Track funding may be appropriate).
Equipment required as assessed by Rehab Team (commode etc.).
Referral to community services listed above.
Anticipatory ‘just in case medications'.
Detailed discharge summary (include details of escalation care planning).
Telephone handover and update by ward to GP.
Ambulance (single patient, stretcher) transport.
Message in a bottle.
Indefinite DNACPR form if in place.
Community contact leaflet.
Oxygen (if required).
Care in the last days of life

Priorities for care of the Dying Person are best practice when it is thought that a person may die within the next few days or hours (Leadership Alliance for the Care of Dying People, 2014). The Leadership Alliance states there are five priorities:
Priorities for Care of the Dying Person
Communication

Communication must be of the best standard between the patient, family and professionals. Where the patient has had a progressive illness, open discussion regarding end of life care may have already been started. However, this must not be assumed. Explore with the dying person and those important to them whether they have an advance statement or has stated preferences about their care in the last days of life and for details of any legal lasting power of attorney for health and welfare. It is necessary to establish the communication needs and expectations of the patients and how they would like to be communicated to.

When the patient enters the last days and hours of life the named multi-disciplinary team led by the senior doctor will need to initiate discussion about the end of life and impending expected death, including care to support the patient during their last days of life. The patient and family must be given the name of the senior doctor who has overall responsibility for care and the name of the nurse responsible for leading the care of the dying person, and how care is handed over. Details of relevant services to support out of hours should be available. The likelihood that the patient may die with the next few days or hours should be recognised and clearly communicated with the patient (where possible) and with their family.

Communication should be sensitive and discuss decisions, actions and care planned in accordance with the patient's needs and wishes. It is necessary for the staff to check the patient's understanding and insight into their condition, how much they would like to know and whether family members should be present. According to the patient's wishes, the discussion should be open and honest, allowing room for questions and thoughts. The dying person should be given all the help and support they need to make a decision before anyone concludes that they cannot make a decision. Where the patient lacks capacity, then an assessment of their mental capacity may be required and decisions may need to be made in their best interests, in consideration of any known preferences, and the family should be consulted as part of the process. Teams caring for the patient need to comply with MSEPO-21103 Mental Capacity Act Policy and as per GMC guidance, ‘End of life care: Adults who lack capacity to decide':
https://www.gmc- uk.org/guidance/ethical_guidance/end_of_life_adults_lacking_capacity_to_decide.a sp
All significant conversations must be documented in the patient's care plan and communicated to the multi-disciplinary team.

It is vital that the patient is reviewed daily and the family are supported regularly and during the usual ward round. Not continuing to see patient routinely prevents regular symptom review and monitoring and can result in patient and family feeling abandoned. All reviews, subsequent decision making and any revision of care planning should be communicated to the patient (where possible) and the family. All reviews must be documented in patient notes and care plan.
Individual plan of care and the Last Days of Life Care Plan

When all reversible causes of deterioration have been ruled out and it is thought that the patient is entering their last days of life the multidisciplinary team, led by the senior doctor responsible for the patient's care, must assess the patient's needs (outlined below) and develop an individual care plan to support symptom control, psycho-social, spiritual and food and drink needs. This should be discussed and agreed with the patient (where possible) and their family. It is best practice to use ‘The Last Days of life Care Plan' to document care plan. These needs should be reviewed daily.
Where it is thought that a person may be entering the last days of life, gather and document information on:
The person's physiological, psychological, social and spiritual needs.
Current clinical signs and symptoms.
Medical history and the clinical context, including underlying diagnoses.
The person's goals and wishes.
The views of those important to the person about future care.
Physical assessment of needs

A physical assessment allows an understanding and documentation of the physical condition of the patient. This may identify specific symptoms or needs that must be addressed and managed, such as the ability to swallow oral medications, which would be reviewed and medications converted to an alternative route of delivery if necessary to continue for symptom control needs.
Review of interventions

Multi–disciplinary assessment led by a senior medical doctor should be made of those interventions that now may need review, such as blood sampling, vital sign monitoring and medications. Detailed assessments must be documented in the clinical case notes. Any interventions that the multidisciplinary team feel is beneficial for the patient – such as paracetamol for pyrexia as a comfort measure must be communicated and documented.
Avoid undertaking investigations that are unlikely to affect care in the last few days of life unless there is a clinical need to do so.
Be aware that improvement in signs and symptoms or functional observations could indicate that the person may be stabilising or recovering.
Food and fluids

All patients should be assessed by the MDT for their ability to eat and drink safely (take oral fluids and diet) and where required referred to Speech and Language Therapist. The assessment process must be conducted openly and family involved where possible as they may provide helpful information to aid the assessment, and provided with clear explanations of the assessment and outcome. Where a patient chooses to eat or drink, even if deemed at risk this must be respected (see Dysphagia Policy MSEPO-21158). This may require Risk Feeding, please refer to policy and protocol regarding this, so that if the patient becomes adequately alert he/she may be given fluids and/or solids as per the Risk Feeding guidelines. This assessment should be clearly documented and reviewed regularly as required. A care plan must be formulated to meet any needs to support and assist the patient to eat and drink and in line with nutrition and hydration policy.
Artificial hydration and nutrition

‘Providing nutrition and hydration by tube or drip may provide symptom relief, or prolong or improve the quality of the patient's life; but they may also present problems. The current evidence about the benefits, burdens and risks of these techniques as patients approach the end of life is not clear-cut. This can lead to concerns that patients who are unconscious or semi-conscious may be experiencing distressing symptoms and complications, or otherwise be suffering either because their needs for nutrition or hydration are not being met or because attempts to meet their perceived needs for nutrition or hydration may be causing them avoidable suffering' (GMC 2015).

The need for clinically assisted hydration (CAH) and clinically assisted nutrition (CAN) should be assessed and discussed with patient, family and multi-disciplinary team. This process needs to be clearly documented and reviewed as required.

Nutrition and hydration provided by tube or drip are regarded in law as medical treatment, and should be treated in the same way as other medical interventions. It is important that the multi-disciplinary team listen and consider the views of the patient and their family (taking into account cultural and religious views).The team should explain the issues to be considered, including the benefits and burdens and risks of providing CAH and CAN. It is vital that patients, their family and the multi- disciplinary team understand that, when CAH or CAN would be of overall benefit, it will always be offered. Equally, that where the decision is taken not to use CAH/ CAN, the patient will continue to receive high quality care with symptoms addressed (GMC 2015).
Advise them that, for someone who is in the last days of life:
Clinically assisted hydration may relieve distressing symptoms or signs related to dehydration, but may cause other problems.
It is uncertain if giving clinically assisted hydration will prolong life or extend the dying process.
It is uncertain if not giving clinically assisted hydration will hasten death.

Following an individual assessment (including their level of consciousness and risk of pulmonary oedema) as to whether CAH may be of benefit, consider a therapeutic trial of clinically assisted hydration if the person has distressing symptoms or signs that could be associated with dehydration, such as thirst or delirium, and oral hydration is inadequate.
Medication review, symptom control and comfort

When it is recognised that a person may be entering the last days of life, review their current medicines and, after discussion and agreement with the dying person and those important to them (as appropriate), stop any previously prescribed medicines that are not providing symptomatic benefit or that may cause harm. Review symptom management at least daily.
Assessment and management of the patient's symptoms should be made taking into account:
The likely cause of the symptom.
The dying person's preferences alongside the benefits and harms of the medicine.
Any individual or cultural views that might affect their choice.
Any risks of the medicine that could affect prescribing decisions, (i.e. prescribing cyclizine to manage nausea and vomiting may exacerbate heart failure).

All medications prescribed must be clinically appropriate and aimed at managing the specific symptoms the patient has in the smallest effective dose for the shortest time necessary. Symptom management must be reviewed regularly and adjusted as required. Consider using a syringe pump to deliver medicines for continuous symptom control if more than 2 or 3 doses of any ‘as required' medicines have been given within 24 hours, please refer to local syringe pump policies for guidance. Where a syringe pump is required to deliver medication the use and management of this must be discussed with the patient (where possible) and the family.

Care must be planned to focus on the patient's comfort needs, including personal hygiene, food, drink, skin and mouth care. The patient's condition must be monitored and needs assessed and documented at regularly (i.e.: every four hours) and documented on the care plan, comfort care rounds or Nerve Centre observations.
Anticipatory prescribing of ‘Just in case' medications

Medications should be prescribed in advance to treat the following 5 anticipated symptoms in the last days of life. Prescribers must ensure intention of use is clearly documented on the prescription. On Wellsky ePMA (where used), prescribers should look up the anticipatory medicated symptoms control protocol.
Pain.
Agitation.
Chest secretions/ noisy and rattily breathing.
Breathlessness.
Nausea.
Privacy, dignity & compassion

It is imperative to maintain the patient's privacy and dignity. This will also be positive for the family who will see that their relative is both valued and respected. Every effort should be made to offer the patient a side room where this is possible, which will allow open visiting and space for the patient and family to spend time together.
Psycho-social care
Assessment of the patient's psycho-social needs is necessary to identify, where possible, the support that is needed and whether the patient has any preferences or practical needs.

On-going assessment into the patient's level of understanding and insight will allow appropriate psychological support to be provided. Compassion and understanding are essential components of all aspects of psychological and emotional support. Support for any outstanding social needs should be offered where possible, discussed with patient and family the facilities available to them to meet their needs.
Spiritual and cultural needs
An assessment of the patient's spiritual and cultural needs is necessary to identify what is important to them and whether the patient has any preferences or practical needs.

Dying patients must be enabled to address their spiritual, religious and cultural needs. Staff need to discuss this openly, document clearly and inform staff caring for the patient to make any necessary arrangements to meet any needs identified. The on-going spiritual care plan needs to be recorded on the Last Days of Life Care Plan.

Where it has been identified that the patient has needs for pastoral care and wishes to be supported by the chaplaincy team, refer to chaplaincy service (see Appendix 2) or contact their identified community faith lead, documenting all action taken. Documentation of any spiritual care received from the Chaplaincy team is recorded on the Spiritual Care Record.
Families' needs

An assessment of families and carers needs (including spiritual and cultural) should be made to support them during their loved ones last days of life and into bereavement. Where appropriate they should be included (with the patient's consent) in all care management decisions for end of life care. Specific information on what to expect as the patient dies is often very helpful and can manage their fears. Written information should be provided to support verbal information – ‘The last days of life, Information for families and carers'. They should be afforded the appropriate environment and facilities to meet their physical and emotional needs.

Provision of dedicated areas for rest and refreshments should be made available. At ward level families should be offered light snacks and refreshments at regular intervals without the need to request this. Provision of overnight stay facilities should be made available, including arrangement of an overnight bed. Verbal and written information regarding car parking, concessions and access to Hospital site out of hours should be made available and supplied to the family by the nurse caring for their relative.

Open visiting should be available for the number of visitors the patient wishes, whilst taking into account the needs of other patients. The Nurse in charge of the ward will need to regularly monitor this to ensure patient's wishes are met.

Consideration of family's spiritual, religious and cultural needs where possible and appropriate, including identification of whether they have any preferences or practical needs that can be met. Where this is identified arrangement should be made to meet these needs.

Families often know the patient's practical and physical needs expertly. To promote comfort and to meet these needs, the family should be enabled to participate in all aspects of care as appropriate, if they so wish, and with patient agreement.
Deactivation of Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator

If the patient is fitted with and ICD this will need to be deactivated – refer to local guidelines. Ideally the plan for deactivation should be assessed and implemented before death and documented on the Last Days of Life Care Plan or patients notes, this will prevent unnecessary shock to the patient as they die.

For those patients where deactivation hasn't occurred, notify the mortuary team who will arrange deactivation as per Guidelines. Ensure this is clearly documented on handover to the portering and mortuary teams.

Appendix 1: Notification of seriously ill patients
This situation is defined as a change in the patient's condition which is life threatening, or is giving the nursing and medical staff cause for concern.

The nominated relative/carer must be made aware of the patient's condition throughout the patient's stay in hospital. This information must be communicated on a regular basis, and a summary of the information given recorded in the patient's notes.
The name, address and telephone number of the relative/carer to be contacted in the case of deterioration of the patient, should be recorded in the patient's case notes

Appendix 2: Referral for pastoral care to chaplaincy team
Routine Referrals
For routine referrals please ring chaplaincy service with referral details.
Include patient's name, ward and referring clinician's name.
Where necessary leave a message. Contact will be made within 24 working hours.
Urgent Referrals
In the event of urgent pastoral or spiritual distress and of care being required, please call Chaplaincy service via switchboard and request to bleep Chaplain on call.
Please supply with referral details, patients name, ward and referring clinician name. Patient requests own faith Leader
The patient or family will usually have contact details.
Where possible please facilitate and make a call on behalf of patient.
Where there are any difficulties or contact details are not known, please contact chaplaincy department as above.
